name: Orion
description: Orion is a prominent constellation located on the celestial equator and visible throughout the world. It is one of the most conspicuous and recognizable constellations in the night sky. Orion's Belt, formed by three bright stars (Mintaka, Alnilam, and Alnitak), makes it easy to identify.
mythology: In Greek mythology, Orion was a supernaturally strong hunter, the son of Poseidon. He was placed in the stars by Zeus after his death. Various myths describe his death, including being killed by a scorpion sent by Gaia, which is why Orion and Scorpius are placed on opposite sides of the sky.

name: Ursa Major
description: Ursa Major is visible throughout the year from most of the northern hemisphere. Its seven brightest stars form the Big Dipper (or Plough) asterism, one of the most recognizable patterns in the night sky. The two stars Dubhe and Merak point toward Polaris, the North Star.
mythology: In Greek mythology, Ursa Major represents Callisto, a beautiful nymph and follower of Artemis. Zeus fell in love with her, and to hide his affair from Hera, he transformed Callisto into a bear. Later, Zeus placed her among the stars.

name: Ursa Minor
description: Ursa Minor contains the Little Dipper asterism. Polaris, the North Star, is located at the end of the dipper's handle and has been used for navigation for centuries. Despite its fame, Polaris is not the brightest star in the sky, but its position near the celestial north pole makes it invaluable.
mythology: Often associated with Arcas, the son of Callisto, who was transformed into a bear by Zeus. To save Arcas from accidentally killing his mother Callisto, Zeus placed both of them in the sky as the Great and Little Bears.

name: Cassiopeia
description: Cassiopeia is easily recognizable due to its distinctive 'W' or 'M' shape, formed by five bright stars. The constellation is circumpolar in many northern latitudes, meaning it never sets below the horizon.
mythology: Named after the vain queen Cassiopeia in Greek mythology, who boasted that her beauty surpassed even the Nereids. As punishment for her vanity, she was placed in the sky tied to her throne.

name: Scorpius
description: Scorpius is a striking constellation in the southern sky, near the center of the Milky Way. Its brightest star, Antares, is a red supergiant whose name means 'rival of Mars' due to its reddish color.
mythology: Represents the scorpion that stung and killed Orion the Hunter in Greek mythology. The gods placed both in the sky on opposite sides so they would never meet again.

name: Sagittarius
description: Sagittarius is commonly depicted as a centaur drawing a bow. The constellation contains the Teapot asterism. Most importantly, Sagittarius lies in the direction of the center of our Milky Way galaxy.
mythology: Often identified as the centaur Chiron or Crotus, the satyr son of Pan. Unlike the wild centaur Centaurus, Sagittarius is depicted as civilized.

name: Leo
description: Leo contains many bright stars and is one of the most easily recognizable constellations. The 'Sickle' asterism marks the lion's head and mane, while Denebola marks its tail.
mythology: Represents the Nemean Lion, a fearsome beast with an impenetrable hide slain by Heracles as the first of his twelve labors.

name: Taurus
description: Taurus is a large and prominent constellation in the northern hemisphere's winter sky. It hosts two famous star clusters: the Pleiades (Seven Sisters) and the Hyades.
mythology: Most commonly associated with Zeus, who transformed himself into a beautiful white bull to abduct Europa, the princess of Phoenicia.

name: Gemini
description: Gemini is dominated by its two brightest stars, Castor and Pollux, which represent the heads of the mythological twins. Castor is a remarkable sextuple star system.
mythology: Represents the twins Castor and Pollux in Greek mythology. When Castor died, Pollux asked Zeus to share his immortality, and they were placed together in the stars.

name: Andromeda
description: Andromeda is located north of the celestial equator. Its most famous feature is the Andromeda Galaxy (M31), the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way at 2.5 million light-years away.
mythology: Named after Andromeda, the daughter of Cassiopeia and Cepheus. She was chained to a rock as a sacrifice but was saved by Perseus.

name: Cygnus
description: Cygnus is recognizable for the Northern Cross asterism, which dominates the summer sky. Deneb is one of the most luminous stars known and forms part of the Summer Triangle.
mythology: Represents a swan and is associated with several Greek myths. The most common identifies it as Zeus in swan form, who seduced Leda.

name: Lyra
description: Lyra is a small but prominent constellation. Its brightest star, Vega, is the fifth-brightest star in the night sky and was the northern pole star around 12,000 BC.
mythology: Represents the lyre of Orpheus, the legendary musician and poet in Greek mythology. His music was so beautiful that even stones and wild beasts were moved.

name: Crux
description: Crux, or the Southern Cross, is the smallest of all the 88 modern constellations but is one of the most distinctive. It has been used for navigation for centuries.
mythology: The Southern Cross was visible from Mediterranean latitudes in ancient times but was 'lost' due to precession. It became important in navigation and folklore of southern hemisphere cultures.

name: Aquarius
description: Aquarius is a faint constellation in the zodiac, representing the figure of a man pouring water from a jar. The stream of water flows toward Piscis Austrinus.
mythology: Often identified with Ganymede, a beautiful youth snatched by Zeus to become the cup-bearer of the gods on Mount Olympus.

name: Aries
description: Aries is a mid-sized constellation in the northern hemisphere. Although relatively faint, it has been identified as a ram since Babylonian times.
mythology: Represents the ram whose Golden Fleece was sought by Jason and the Argonauts. The golden-fleeced ram was sent by Nephele to rescue her children Phrixus and Helle.

name: Virgo
description: Virgo is the largest constellation in the zodiac and the second-largest constellation overall. Virgo contains the Virgo Cluster, a collection of over 1,300 galaxies.
mythology: Associated with multiple goddesses including Dike (goddess of justice), Demeter (goddess of the harvest), and Persephone (goddess of spring).
